reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing step: the author’s move from economic ρ estimates to “their implied max speed is implausibly low, so ρ is probably closer to 0,” which helps justify discounting the main quantitative bottleneck objection and supports the stated SIE probability. However, the position has several other independent counters (long-run ρ, experiment efficiency, heroic extrapolation, non-compute routes), so even fully undercutting this pivot would not collapse the whole case (moderate centrality). The critique substantially weakens the pivot by noting it risks being an intuition-based restatement of the desired conclusion and by highlighting an unmodeled constraint—sequential, high-confidence, near-frontier validation under fixed compute—under which low ceilings could be quite plausible. But it doesn’t provide its own quantitative evidence that a 6–10× ceiling is likely, so it’s more a methodological/epistemic undercut than a decisive refutation (moderate strength). Claims made are largely plausible and consistent with ML practice (integration/regression/validation costs), and the argument is clear and tightly focused with little fluff.
title: Calling low max speed implausible assumes progress scales with labor, not validation limits
